program main

implicit none

integer(8) :: n, A(100000) ! assuming n can be up to 1e5? The first Java code uses an array of size n. Need to set a sufficiently large size. 

integer(8) :: ans, div, pow2(0:59), i, j, count1, term

integer(8) :: input_n, m, current_i

div = 10**9 +7

!

Read input

read*, n

allocate(A(n)) !
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text:
So:

read*, n

allocate(A(n)) do i =1, n

   read*, A(i)

end do

! Compute pow2 array

allocate(pow2(0:59))

pow2(0) = 1

do i=1,59

   pow2(i) = mod(2*pow2(i-1), div)

end do

! Compute ans

ans =0

do i=0,59

   count1 =0

   do j=1, n

      if (btest(A(j), i)) then

         count1 = count1 +1

      end if

   end do

   term = mod( count1*(n - count1) * pow2(i), div )

   ans = mod(ans + term, div)

end do

! Now process the second part

input_n = ans

m = input_n

! First print

write(*, '(I0, A)', advance='no') m, ' '

!

Putting it all together:

But need to make sure that the pow2 array is properly allocated.

segments.text:
Alternatively, since 0:59 is fixed, we can declare it as integer(8), dimension(0:59) :: pow2. So modifying the code:

program main

implicit none

integer(8) :: n, ans, div, input_n, m, current_i

integer(8), allocatable :: A(:)

integer(8), dimension(0:59) :: pow2

div = 10**9 +7

!
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text:
Read input

read*, n

allocate(A(n))

read*, A(1:n)

! Compute pow2 array

pow2(0) = 1

do i=1,59

   pow2(i) = mod(2*pow2(i-1), div)

end do

! Compute ans

ans =0

do i=0,59

   integer(8) :: count1 =0

   do j=1, n

      if (btest(A(j), i)) then

         count1 = count1 +1

      end if

   end do

   integer(8) :: term = mod( count1*(n - count1) * pow2(i), div )

   ans = mod(ans + term, div)

end do

! Process second part

input_n = ans

m = input_n

! First print

write(*, '(I0, A)') m, ' '

do current_i = input_n -1, 1, -1

   if (mod(m, current_i) == 0) then 

      write(*, '(I0, A)') current_i, ' '

      m = current_i

   end if 

end do 

deallocate(A)

end program main

then loop over j.

program main

implicit none

integer(8) :: n, A(100000) ! assuming n can be up to 1e5? The first Java code uses an array of size n. Need to set a sufficiently large size. 

integer(8) :: ans, div, pow2(0:59), i, j, count1, term

integer(8) :: input_n, m, current_i

div = 10**9 +7

! Read input

read*, n

allocate(A(n)) ! Wait, but in Fortran, arrays are declared with fixed size. Hmm, but if n can be up to 1e5, maybe better to read n first, then allocate. 

Wait, in Fortran, you can use allocatable arrays. 

So:

integer(8), allocatable :: A(:)

read*, n

allocate(A(n))

do i =1, n

   read*, A(i)

end do

! Compute pow2 array

allocate(pow2(0:59))

pow2(0) = 1

do i=1,59

   pow2(i) = mod(2*pow2(i-1), div)

end do

! Compute ans

ans =0

do i=0,59

   count1 =0

   do j=1, n

      if (btest(A(j), i)) then

         count1 = count1 +1

      end if

   end do

   term = mod( count1*(n - count1) * pow2(i), div )

   ans = mod(ans + term, div)

end do

! Now process the second part

input_n = ans

m = input_n

! First print

write(*, '(I0, A)', advance='no') m, ' '

! Wait, but in Java it's a println, so after the space, a new line.

Putting it all together:

But need to make sure that the pow2 array is properly allocated. 

Wait, in the code above, after reading n, we allocate A(n). Then, we allocate pow2(0:59). 

Wait, in Fortran, arrays can be declared with fixed sizes. Since 60 elements is small, perhaps better to declare it as a fixed array. 

Alternatively, use an allocatable array. 

Alternatively, since 0:59 is fixed, we can declare it as integer(8), dimension(0:59) :: pow2. 

So modifying the code:

program main

implicit none

integer(8) :: n, ans, div, input_n, m, current_i

integer(8), allocatable :: A(:)

integer(8), dimension(0:59) :: pow2

div = 10**9 +7

! Read input

read*, n

allocate(A(n))

read*, A(1:n)

! Compute pow2 array

pow2(0) = 1

do i=1,59

   pow2(i) = mod(2*pow2(i-1), div)

end do

! Compute ans

ans =0

do i=0,59

   integer(8) :: count1 =0

   do j=1, n

      if (btest(A(j), i)) then

         count1 = count1 +1

      end if

   end do

   integer(8) :: term = mod( count1*(n - count1) * pow2(i), div )

   ans = mod(ans + term, div)

end do

! Process second part

input_n = ans

m = input_n

! First print

write(*, '(I0, A)') m, ' '

do current_i = input_n -1, 1, -1

   if (mod(m, current_i) == 0) then 

      write(*, '(I0, A)') current_i, ' '

      m = current_i

   end if 

end do 

deallocate(A)

end program main
